newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish bonds slide with Europe, eye Buba meeting.
newsitem.headline: Irish bonds slide with Europe, eye Buba meeting.

text.p: Irish government bonds lost ground across the curve in brisk trading on Wednesday afternoon as most European markets were nervy in advance of a possible repo rate cut at Thursday's Bundesbank meeting, dealers said. "Irish
bonds have been slipping gradually all day because of panicky European markets. Dealers are still divided on whether a German repo cut is on the cards," one dealer said.
By 1515 GMT, the 8.00 percent bond due 2000 was down 37 pence from Tuesday's close at 103.55 to yield 6.85 percent.
The 8.00 percent bond due 2006 was down 35 pence from the close at 102.95 to yield 7.43 percent.
The German Ifo business climate index came in stronger than expected at 94.1 and dealers said any repo rate cut tomorrow was now likely to be kept to a minimum.
"The Irish market has fallen in anticipation of a small German repo cut on Thursday. Most analysts would now be expecting a minimum cut in the repo rate," one dealer said.
In the UK, gilts made half-point losses across the curve at closing as dealers said the only thing that could stablise the market was a German repo cut.
Earlier, UK retail sales for July showed a surprise drop of 0.6 percent after a 1.4 percent jump in June, dealers said.
